channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Qaddafi’s Son Hannibal Is Said to Be Abducted in Lebanon
item.description: The National News Agency said the son, Hannibal Qaddafi, who appeared in a video broadcast on Lebanese television, was seized Thursday by kidnappers.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Burundi Military Sites Attacked by Gunmen in Capital
item.description: The assaults raised tensions in an African nation pulsing with violence since President Pierre Nkurunziza won a controversial third term in office.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON

item.title: Egypt Intensifying Crackdown on Journalists, Rights Group Says
item.description: The Committee to Protect Journalists said that the number of detentions of journalists in the country is at its highest point since 1991.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: AMINA ISMAIL and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Key to Success of Climate Pact Will Be Its Signals to Global Markets
item.description: Diplomats and policy experts say that a pact must convince companies and investors that traditional fossil fuels are less profitable.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Opinion: The Global Face of Student Protest
item.description: In South Africa and other countries around the world, activists are posing the same questions Americans are about who belongs where.
item.dc:creator: EVE FAIRBANKS
item.media:description: Students cheered as the statue of Cecil Rhodes was removed from the University of Cape Town.

item.title: Bomb Rocks Kabul’s Diplomatic Quarter and Starts a Standoff
item.description: A car bombing opened the Taliban’s latest attack in Kabul, and officials said the attackers took shelter in or near a guesthouse for the Spanish Embassy.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and AHMAD SHAKIB

item.title: Murder Charges Filed Against Previously Imprisoned Russian Oligarch
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, once Russia’s richest man and now a resident of London, dismissed the new charges as politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: In These Hard Times, How Do You Talk to Your Children About Being Muslim?
item.description: The Times wants to hear from Muslim parents about how they talk to their children about the rise in anti-Muslim speech as well as attacks by extremists in the name of Islam.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A Muslim women joined a rally in support of Syrian and Iraqi refugees in New York on Thursday.

item.title: Spain Arrests Terrorism Suspect in Plot Against Swedish Artist
item.description: Ali Charaf Damache, a dual Algerian and Irish citizen, was arrested in Barcelona and is accused of planning to set up terrorist training camps and kill several Westerners.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Victory for France’s Right-Wing Party Appears to Be Imperiled
item.description: The Socialists withdrew from races across the country to unify with the Republicans against the far-right National Front party, led by Marine Le Pen.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Alibaba Buying South China Morning Post, Aiming to Influence Media
item.description: The Chinese Internet giant said the deal was fueled by a desire to improve China’s image and offer an alternative to the biased lens of Western news outlets.
item.dc:creator: DAVID BARBOZA
item.media:description: The South China Morning Post is Hong Kong's leading English language newspaper.

item.title: A New Problem Bites Israel’s Prime Minister
item.description: Kaiya, the Netanyahu family dog, had to be quarantined under Israeli law this week for biting two guests at the prime minister’s Hanukkah party.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu showed Secretary of State John Kerry his dog Kaiya at g a meeting in Jerusalem last month.

item.title: China’s Emissions Pledges Are Undercut by Boom in Coal Projects Abroad
item.description: Chinese banks and firms have built or are in contracts to build at least 92 coal-fired power plants in 27 countries, undermining efforts on climate change.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:credit: Christian Berg for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Duyen Hai complex in Tra Vinh Province is one of several coal-fired power plants that Chinese firms are building in Vietnam.

item.title: Iraqi Campaign to Retake Ramadi From ISIS Makes Gains
item.description: After months of false starts and unfulfilled promises by Iraqi and American leaders for quick gains, a recent siege has finally yielded some success.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: OMAR AL-JAWOSHY, FALIH HASSAN and TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces took combat positions on Thursday at the front line against Islamic State militants in Ramadi, the capital of Anbar, a vast Sunni-dominated region in western Iraq.

item.title: Gloves Come Off (Again) in Ukraine’s Parliament
item.description: This brawl was particularly fierce, erupting after the prime minister was physically lifted by a member of an opposing party.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere: North Korean Pop Group Visits Beijing on Soft-Power Mission
item.description: The all-female Moranbong Band, Kim Jong-un’s favorite group, is visiting Beijing at a time when China and North Korea are trying to strengthen ties.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and OWEN GUO
item.media:description: Members of the Moranbong Band from North Korea in Beijing on Friday.

item.title: Syrian Refugees Greeted by Justin Trudeau in Canada
item.description: “You are home,” Mr. Trudeau said 163 refugees after they landed in Toronto, the first of 25,000 the country has promised to take in.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Nathan Denette/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau on Friday greeted Syrian refugees arriving in Toronto.

item.title: Britain Ends Inquiry Into Phone-Hacking Scandal
item.description: Prosecutors said there was not enough evidence for further charges in the four-year investigation into excesses in the tabloid news media.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere: A Wordless Elegy for China’s War Dead
item.description: A requiem for the millions of Chinese killed during World War II and in the years leading up to it will take to the stage in Beijing just once.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The composer Wang Xilin at his home in Beijing. His symphony will have its premiere on Dec. 13.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Return of History
item.description: From the Islamic State to Sri Lanka, modern people are looking to connect with an ancient past.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER
